Camp Tudor Place

Exploration and authenticity are the hallmarks of camp at Tudor Place.

LSD to OMG!

Comedian Will Durst has been called ‘an equal opportunity offender’ by some critics. “Not exactly,” says Durst who sat down with Hollywood on the Potomac to talk about his one man show in Washington. “An equal opportunity offender means taking out both sides. And yes.

Fans of arthouse movie theatre, West End Cinema, closed since March, will be pleased to note they are returning July 17, 2015.

This Beach is Metro Accessible

Visit the National Building Museum through September 7, 2015 and experience an interactive architectural installation that brings the quintessential summer experience of going to the beach to downtown Washington, D.C.

Celebrate 25 Years of The Americans With Disability Act

The Kennedy Center and Smithsonian Institution are hosting a one-of-a-kind celebration of arts, culture, and history this July. This celebration is brimming with world-class performances and events—music, art, dance, film—all free and open to everyone.

If you’re hooked on CNN’s Original Series, you’re not alone.

Summer scultpure at Watergate Gallery & Frame Design from Juy 11 through August 15, 2015.

An Open Letter to Bernie Sanders and His Supporters

Dear Bernie and your passionate supporters: First let me say thank you for joining the discussion to raise some very important issues as we begin the campaign to see who will be our next President.

Hop, Cask & Barrel of Georgetown

There are many reasons to visit Hop, Cask & Barrel, Georgetown's newest wine and spirits store. Let's start with my top three:

'DIHISCENT: Out of the Closet & Off the Walls'

Addison/Ripley Fine Art presents an interesting new group exhibition, DIHISCENT: Out of the Closet & Off the Walls opening, Friday July 10 and continuing through August 21, 2015

Summer Specials at 1789

Now through September 11, excluding Saturdays, head to one of Georgetown's most elegant restaurants, 1789, for an incredible three-course meal (choose from first or second, main, and dessert

by guest contributor Dimitrios Machairidis

'Pleasure and Piety: The Art of Joachim Wtewael '

Through October 4, 2015, visit the west building of the National Gallery of Art to see the risque mythological scenes of masterful storyteller, Joachim Wtewael (1566 – 1638).

Singin’ in the Rain

Believe it: Washington’s own Kandie Stroud got to sing back up for Barry Manilow for PBS’s Fourth of July celebration on the mall!

JFK Self-Guided Georgetown Walking Tour

The Georgetown Business Improvement District has announced a self-guided tour of the Georgetown that John F. and Jacqueline Kennedy called home.

Grace Church 22nd Annual Bach Festival

Visit Georgetown's historic Grace Church to experience Johann Sebastian Bach's most iconic works as they come alive.

Urban Chic Closing Sale

From now through the end of July, visit Urban Chic as they prepare to close after 10+ years in Georgetown's Book Hill area. Take 35% off with additional markdowns expected as the merchandise sells out.

Tinos Remains a Paradise

The tide comes in an out. The monks chant. The wind blows. The bells of the church ring. All seems to be well, normal, on the Greek island of Tinos. We have been coming here for the past six years, and these are all “normal” things indeed.

EastBanc Eyes Gas Station for Apartments

By Brady HoltCurrent Staff Writer

At the gateway to Georgetown — between Pennsylvania Avenue and M Street across from the Four Seasons hotel — visitors to the historic neighborhood are currently greeted by a small gas station and a jumble of cars in various states of repair.

Washington Fine Properties (WFP) announced Monday the opening of its newest office in Washington D.C.

July 3rd and July 4th Gyspy Sally's is offering a fun and unique way to spend the 4th of July weekend!

Georgetown Sunset Cinema Tuesday Evenings

On Tuesday nights starting July 7, the Georgetown Business Improvement District (BID) kicks off Georgetown Sunset Cinema, Georgetown’s first-ever outdoor movie experience, through August 4.

Jean Carne Celebrates 40 Years at Blues Alley

Performing live at Blues Alley for four nights beginning Thursday, July 9, 2015 is soul legend, Jean Carne.

Jessica Alba Lobbies The Hill

Do not call Jessica Alba a starlet. Many people might know the 34-year-old as an actress from Sin City, The Fantastic Four or TV’s Dark Angel; but these days, Alba is all business and she wants you to know it.

Ellington’s Ballooning Cost Sparks D.C. Audit

By Katie PearceCurrent Staff Writer

Over the years, costs for the renovation of the Duke Ellington School of the Arts have ballooned from $71 million to now nearly $178.5 million. The D.C. auditor is now trying to figure out exactly how that happened.

Ambassador Herman Cohen Releases Book on African Leaders

Ambassador and former Assistant Secretary of State, Herman J. “Hank” Cohen, long-time Georgetown resident and author of Intervening in Africa: Superpower Peacemaking in a Troubled Continent, has published his second book on modern Africa.

There will be a public safety meeting at Dumbarton House on June 25th starting at 7:00 pm.
'A Woman Who Does Not Wear Perfume Has No Future'

Live Music Wednesday Evenings at Washington Harbour

The Washington Harbour is presenting its live music series for summer, Harbour Nights, every Wednesday evening, 6:30 to 8:30 pm through September 30.

Two Mega Stars in One Week

Singer/songwriter Michael Bolton dined on Marina pizza Tuesday for lunch at il Canale. He gained his first major hit as a songwriter, co-writing "How Am I Supposed To Live Without You."

Another major hit was "When A Man Loves A Woman."

Celebrate Father's Day at Bistrot Lepic

Treat Dad and the whole family to something special this year. Bistrot Lepic & Wine Bar is offering a $25 gift certificate to the "Papa" who dines at Bistrot Lepic on June 21, 2015.

Book Hill Dog Parade June 27th

The Book Hill Park Annual Dog Parade and Show is back!

Dogs will meet Uncle Sam, strut in the parade, and compete for prizes (for best costume, best couple, best trick, among others).

Pedestrian Deaths Spur Safety Push

By Brady HoltCurrent Staff Writer

A pair of fatal pedestrian accidents in the Wisconsin Avenue corridor last week has prompted a call for safety improvements along the busy artery, and the D.C. Department of Transportation has pledged to investigate solutions.

'American Moments: Photographs from The Phillips Collection' June 16- Sept. 13

In celebration of recent major gifts, The Phillips Collection presents for the first time a major photography exhibition drawn exclusively from the museum’s permanent collection.

Crumbs & Whiskers Opens June 20th

Georgetown's first cat cafe, Crumbs & Whiskers will officially open on Saturday, June 20, 2015.
